Problem Statement: As shown in the figure, the switch has been in position A for a long time. At $t=0$ it is suddenly moved to position B. What is the time rate of change of the current through $R$ immediately after contact with B?
Solution:
Because the current through an inductor cannot be changed suddenly, we still have

$$
i_{L}(0)=\frac{1}{1}=1 \mathrm{~A} .
$$As $-L \frac{d i_{L}}{d t}=i_{L} R$,

$$
\left.\frac{d i_{L}}{d t}\right|_{t=0}=-i_{L}(0) \frac{R}{L}=1 \times \frac{10^{4}}{1}=-10^{4} \mathrm{~A} / \mathrm{s} .
$$

Problem Statement:
A particle of mass $m$ and momentum $p$ is incident from the left on the potential step shown in the figure.

Calculate the probability that the particle is scattered backward by the potential if $p^{2} / 2 m<V_{0}$

Singlet positronium decays by emitting two photons which are polarized at right angles with respect to each other. An experiment is performed with photon detectors behind polarization analyzers, as shown in Fig. 8.3. Each analyzer has a preferred axis such that light polarized in that direction is transmitted perfectly, while light polarized in the perpendicular direction is absorbed completely. The analyzer axes are at right angles with respect to each other. When many events are observed, what is the ratio of the number of events in which both detectors record a photon to the number in which only one detector records a photon?
Solution:
Suppose the positronium is initially at rest. Then the two photons will move in opposite directions to conserve momentum, and will reach the respective analyzers at the same time. Assume further that the detector solid angle is very smaller. Then the directions of those photons that reach the analyzers must be almost perpendicular to the latter. Hence the directions of polarization of these photons are parallel to the analyzers. Denote by $\theta$ the angle between one photon's direction of polarizationn and the direction of transmission of the analyzer reached by it. The probability that it can pass through the analyzer is $\cos ^{2} \theta$. Consider the second photon produced in the same decay. As it is polarized at right angles with respect to the first one, the angle between its direction of polarization and the direction of transmission of the second analyzer, which is oriented at right angles to that of the first analyzer, is also $\theta$. Hence the probability that, of the two detectors, only one records the passage of a photon is

$$
\begin{aligned}
P_{1} & \propto \Omega\left[\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \cos ^{2} \theta\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right) d \theta+\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi}\left(1-\cos ^{2} \theta\right) \cos ^{2} \theta d \theta\right] \\
&=\frac{\Omega}{4}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $\Omega$ is the solid angle subtended by the detector, and the probability that both detectors record the passage of photons is

$$
P_{2} \propto \Omega\left[\frac{1}{2 \pi} \int_{0}^{2 \pi} \cos ^{2} \theta \cos ^{2} \theta d \theta\right]=\frac{3 \Omega}{8} .
$$

Hence the ratio of the number of events of both detectors recording to that of only one detector recording in a given time is

$$
\frac{P_{2}}{P_{1}}=\frac{3}{8} \div \frac{1}{4}=\frac{3}{2} \text {. }
$$

Problem Statement:
A retro-reflector is an optical device which reflects light back directly whence it came. The most familiar retro-reflector is the reflecting corner cube, but recently the 3M Company invented "Scotchlite" spheres.

Calculate the index of refraction $n$ which enables the sphere to retro-reflect light.
Solution:
The "Scotchlite" sphere is a ball of index of refraction $n$, whose rear semi-spherical interface is a reflecting surface. The focal length in the image space, $f$, for a single refractive interface is given by

$$
f=\frac{n r}{n-1},
$$

where $r$ is the radius of the sphere. The index of refraction of air is unity. The index of refraction of the glass is chosen so that the back focal point of the front semi-spherical interface coincides with the apex of the rear semi-spherical interface (see Fig. 1.18), i.e.,

$$
f=2 r \text {. }
$$

Hence $n=2$.

Problem Statement:
High-energy neutrino beams at Fermi laboratory are made by first forming a monoenergetic $\pi^{+}$(or $K^{+}$) beam and then allowing the pions to decay by $\pi^{+} \rightarrow \mu^{+}+\nu$. Recall that the mass of the pion is $140 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$ and the mass of the muon is $106 \mathrm{MeV} / \mathrm{c}^{2}$.

In laboratory frame, the energy of the neutrino depends on the decay angle $\theta$ (see the figure). Suppose the $\pi^{+}$beam has an energy of $200 \mathrm{GeV}$.

Find the energy of a neutrino produced in the forward direction $(\theta=0)$.
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Units: $\mathrm{GeV}$. Round to 1 decimal point.
Solution:
For convenience use units such that $c=1(m, E, p$ are all in $\mathrm{MeV})$. Consider the Lorentz-invariant and conserved quantity $E^{2}-p^{2}$. In laboratory frame, before the decay

$$
E^{2}-p^{2}=E_{\pi}^{2}-p_{\pi}^{2}=m_{\pi}^{2} .
$$

In the rest frame of the pion, after the decay

$$
\begin{aligned}
E^{\prime 2}-p^{\prime 2} &=\left(E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}-\left(\mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}+\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2} \\
&=\left(E_{\mu}^{\prime}+E_{\nu}^{\prime}\right)^{2}=p_{\mu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}+p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+2 p_{\nu}^{\prime} \sqrt{p_{\mu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}} \\
&=2 p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}+2 p_{\nu}^{\prime} \sqrt{p_{\nu}^{\prime 2}+m_{\mu}^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $\mathbf{p}_{\mu}^{\prime}=-\mathbf{p}_{\nu}^{\prime}$, and $E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime}$ assuming the neutrino to have zero rest mass. Equating the above two expressions gives

$$
E_{\nu}^{\prime}=p_{\nu}^{\prime}=\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2 m_{\pi}}=29.9 \mathrm{MeV} .
$$In the laboratory frame (Fig. 3.21), momentum conservation gives

$$
p_{\pi}=p_{\nu} \cos \theta+p_{\mu} \cos \alpha, \quad p_{\nu} \sin \theta=p_{\mu} \sin \alpha,
$$

or

$$
p_{\mu}^{2}=p_{\pi}^{2}+p_{\nu}^{2}-2 p_{\pi} p_{\nu} \cos \theta,
$$

and energy conservation gives

$$
E_{\pi}=E_{\nu}+E_{\mu} .
$$

As $p_{\nu}=E_{\nu}, p_{\mu}^{2}=E_{\mu}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}$, the last two equations give

$$
p_{\nu}=\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}}{2\left(E_{\pi}-p_{\pi} \cos \theta\right)} .
$$

As $E_{\pi} \gg m_{\pi}$, we have

$$
p_{\pi}=E_{\pi} \sqrt{1-\frac{m_{\pi}^{2}}{E_{\pi}^{2}}} \approx E_{\pi}\left[1-\frac{1}{2}\left(\frac{m_{\pi}}{E_{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right]
$$

and hence

$$
E_{\nu}=p_{\nu} \approx \frac{\left(m_{\pi}^{2}-m_{\mu}^{2}\right) E_{\pi}}{2 E_{\pi}^{2}(1-\cos \theta)+m_{\pi}^{2} \cos \theta} .
$$

For neutrinos emitted in the forward direction, $\theta=0$ and

$$
E_{\nu} \approx\left[1-\left(\frac{m_{\mu}}{m_{\pi}}\right)^{2}\right] E_{\pi}=85.4 \mathrm{GeV} \text {. }
$$

Problem Statement:
A laser beam $\left(\lambda=6.3 \times 10^{-5} \mathrm{~cm}\right)$ is directed at grazing incidence onto a steel machinist's ruler (which is calibrated in $1 / 16$ inch). The light reflects from the surface of the ruler and is projected onto a vertical wall 10 meters away (see the figure).

What is the vertical separation on the wall of the zeroth and first order spots of the pattern?
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Units: $\mathrm{m}$. Round to 2 decimal points.
Solution:
The optical path length difference (OPD) of the parallel light rays shown in Fig. $2.61$ is

$$
\Delta=d\left(\cos \theta-\cos \theta^{\prime}\right) \approx d\left(1-\cos \theta^{\prime}\right)
$$

as $\theta \approx 0$. Interference maxima occur when $\Delta=m \lambda$ ( $m$ is an integer), or

$$
\cos \theta^{\prime}=1-m \lambda / d .
$$

When $m=0, \theta^{\prime}=0$. When $m=1, \theta_{1}^{\prime}=1-\lambda / d=0.9996$ taking $d=1$ division ( $\frac{1}{16}$ inch). The vertical separation on the wall between the zeroth and first order spots is

$$
x=l \cdot \tan \theta_{1}^{\prime}=0.28 \mathrm{~m} .
$$

Problem Statement:
The circuit shown in the figure is a relaxation oscillator built from an ideal (infinite open-loop gain, infinite input impedance) differential amplifier. The amplifier saturates at an output of $\pm 10 \mathrm{~V}$.

Calculate the frequency of oscillation for the component values given.
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Units: $\mathrm{Hz}$. Round to 1 decimal point.
Solution:
This is a relaxation oscillator having positive feedback shunted by $R_{1}$ and $R_{2}$ and discharged through an $R C$ circuit. When stability is reached, the output is a rectangular wave with amplitude equal to the saturated voltage. Let $V_{\mathrm{C}}=+10 \mathrm{~V}$. The potential at point $\mathrm{B}$ is $V_{\mathrm{B}}=$ $\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}} \times V_{\mathrm{C}}=2 \mathrm{~V}$. The capacitor $\mathrm{C}$ is charged through $R$, and $V_{\mathrm{A}}$ will increase from $-2 \mathrm{~V}$ to $+2 \mathrm{~V}$. When $V_{\mathrm{A}}$ is higher than $V_{\mathrm{B}}, V_{\mathrm{C}}$ will decrease to $-10 \mathrm{~V}$ and $\mathrm{C}$ will discharge through $R$. When $V_{\mathrm{A}}$ is lower than the potential at $\mathrm{B}$, which is now $\frac{R_{2}}{R_{1}+R_{2}} \times(-10)=-2 \mathrm{~V}, V_{\mathrm{C}}$ will again increase to $+10 \mathrm{~V}$. So following each charging the circuit relaxes back to the starting point, i.e., relaxation oscillation occurs. The charging of the capacitor follows

$$
V=V_{0}[1-\exp (-t / R C)] \text {, or } t=R C \ln \left(\frac{V_{0}}{V_{0}-V}\right) \text {. }
$$

The charging time $T$ from $V_{1}$ to $V_{2}$ is

$$
T=R C \ln \frac{V_{0}-V_{1}}{V_{0}-V_{2}} .
$$

The charging time is given by $V_{0}=10 \mathrm{~V}, V_{1}=-2 \mathrm{~V}, V_{2}=2 \mathrm{~V}$, i.e., $T_{1}=R C \ln \frac{10+2}{10-2}=8.1 \mathrm{~ms}$; the discharging time is given by $V_{0}=-10 \mathrm{~V}$, $V_{1}=2 \mathrm{~V}, V_{2}=-2 \mathrm{~V}$, i.e., $T_{2}=R C \ln \frac{-10-2}{-10+2}=8.1 \mathrm{~ms}$. Hence the oscillation frequency is $\frac{1}{T_{1}+T_{2}}=61.6 \mathrm{~Hz}$.

Problem Statement: A plane monochromatic wave (wavelength $\lambda$) is incident on a set of 5 slits spaced at a distance $d$ (see the figure). You may assume that the width of the individual slits is much less than $d$. For the resulting interference pattern, which is focused on a screen, compute the intensity of subsidiary maximum relative to principal maximum intensity.
Solution:
Each slit contributes an equal phasor $A_{0}$. These contributions can be added up in the phasor diagrams of Fig. 2.56. When $\theta=0$, all the five phasors are in phase and the resultant phasor is a straight line of $A=5 A_{0}$, representing the principal maximum (see Fig. $2.56(\mathrm{a})$ ). For the first minimum, the phasor diagram reduces to a pentagon (see Fig. $2.56$ (b)). Here we have $\delta=\frac{2 \pi d \sin \theta}{\lambda}=\frac{2}{5} \pi$, i.e., $\theta \approx \sin \theta=\frac{\lambda}{5 d}$. For the first

Angular width of central image is $\theta \approx \frac{\lambda}{b d}$.Intensity of subsidiary maximum relative to that of the principal maximum is about

$$
\left(\frac{A_{0}}{5 A_{0}}\right)^{2}=\frac{1}{25} \text {. }
$$

Problem Statement: A double-slit interference is produced by plane parallel light of wavelength $\lambda$ passing through two slits of unequal widths, say $w_{1}=20 \lambda$ and $w_{\Omega}=40 \lambda$, their centers being $1000 \lambda$ apart. If the observation is made on a screen very far away from the slits, i.e., at a distance $L \gg 1000 \lambda$, determine the intensity ratio between intensity maximum and minimum in the center of the pattern.
Solution:
As $w_{2}=2 w_{1}, L>w_{1}, w_{2}$, we may take the amplitudes of the electric field vectors produced by the slits $S_{1}$ and $S_{2}$ individually on the screen to be $E$ and $2 E$ respectively. Since $I \propto E^{2}$, the corresponding intensities are $I_{1}=I_{0}$, say, $I_{2}=4 I_{0}$. For double-slit interference the resultant amplitude is given by the vector sum of $E_{1}$ and $E_{2}$ making an angle $\delta$ equal to the phase difference. Hence

$$
\begin{aligned}
I &=I_{1}+I_{2}+2 \sqrt{I_{1} I_{2}} \cos \delta \\
&=I_{0}+4 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2 \pi d \sin \theta / \lambda)=5 I_{0}+4 I_{0} \cos (2000 \pi \sin \theta),
\end{aligned}
$$

where $d$ is the separation of the centres of the slits, being equal to $1000 \lambda$, $\sin \theta \approx \frac{x}{L}, x$ being the distance on the screen from the centre of the interference pattern. As $L>x, \sin \theta \simeq \theta$ and adjacent maxima occur when $2000 \pi \delta \theta=2 \pi$, or $\delta \theta=\frac{1}{1000}$, giving

$$
\delta x=L \delta \theta=\frac{L}{1000} .
$$The diffraction intensity distribution due to a slit of width $w$ is given by $\sim\left(\frac{\sin \beta}{\beta}\right)^{2}$, where $\beta=\frac{\pi w}{\lambda} \sin \theta$. Thus

$$
\begin{aligned}
&I_{1}=I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{1} / \beta_{1}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{1}=\pi w_{1} \sin \theta / \lambda=20 \pi \sin \theta, \\
&I_{2}=4 I_{0}\left(\sin \beta_{2} / \beta_{2}\right)^{2}, \quad \text { where } \beta_{2}=\pi w_{2} \sin \theta / \lambda=40 \pi \sin \theta .
\end{aligned}
$$

The first zeros occur at angular distances from the centre of $\theta_{1}$ and $\theta_{2}$ given by

$$
20 \pi \sin \theta_{1} \simeq 20 \pi \theta_{1}=\pi \text {, or } \theta_{1}=\frac{1}{20} \text {, and } \theta_{2}=\frac{1}{40} \text {. }
$$

Hence the angular widths of the central maxima are

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \theta_{1}=2 \theta_{1} &=\frac{1}{10}, \\
\Delta \theta_{2} &=\frac{1}{20} .
\end{aligned}
$$

The corresponding widths are then

$$
\begin{aligned}
&\Delta x_{1}=L \theta_{1}=L / 10, \\
&\Delta x_{2}=L \theta_{2}=L / 20 .
\end{aligned}
$$The width of the overlap of these central maxima is $L / 20$, and the number of fringes is $(\mathrm{L} / 20) /(\mathrm{L} / 1000)=50$.The intensity maximum and minimum in the center of the pattern are given by $\cos \delta=1$ and $\cos \delta=-1$ respectively. Hence we have the ratio

$$
\frac{I_{\max }}{I_{\min }}=\frac{9 I_{0}}{I_{0}}=9 .
$$

Problem Statement: In an amusement park there is a rotating horizontal disk. A child can sit on it at any radius (see the figure). As the disk begins to "speed up", the child may slide off if the frictional force is insufficient. The mass of the child is $50 \mathrm{~kg}$ and the coefficient of friction is $0.4$. The angular velocity is $2 \mathrm{rad} / \mathrm{s}$. What is the maximum radius $R$ where he can sit and still remain on the disk?
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Units: $\mathrm{m}$. Round to 2 decimal points.
Solution:
Under the critical circumstance that the child just starts to slide,

$$
m R \omega^{2}=\mu m g .
$$

Hence

$$
R=\frac{\mu g}{\omega^{2}}=\frac{0.4 \times 9.8}{2^{2}}=0.98 \mathrm{~m} .
$$

As the centrifugal force is proportional to the radius, this is the maximum radius for no-sliding.

Problem Statement:
Low energy neutrons from a nuclear reactor have been used to test gravitationally induced quantum interference. In the figure, neutrons incident from $\mathrm{A}$ can follow two paths of equal lengths, $\mathrm{ABCEF}$ and $\mathrm{ABDEF}$, and interfere after they recombine at $E$. The three parallel slabs which diffract the neutrons are cut from one single crystal. To change the effects of the gravitational potential energy, the system can be rotated about the line ABD. Suppose $\phi$ is the angle of this rotation $(\phi=0$ for the path ABCEF horizontal).

The neutron wavelength used in the experiment is $1.45 \AA$. What is the corresponding kinetic energy in electron volts?

Mass of neutron $=939 \mathrm{MeV} / c^{2}, \hbar c=1.97 \times 10^{-11} \mathrm{MeV} \cdot \mathrm{cm}$.
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Units: $\mathrm{eV}$. Round to 3 decimal points.
Solution:
The wave function of the incident neutrons can be taken as

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=c e^{(i \mathbf{p} \cdot \mathbf{r}-i E t) / \hbar}
$$

where $c$ is a constant. When they move along a certain orbit from $x=0$ to $x=l$ it becomes

$$
\psi(\mathbf{r}, t)=c \exp \left[\frac{i}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{l} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)} d x-\frac{i}{\hbar} E t\right]
$$

Thus the phase is

$$
\varphi=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{l} \sqrt{2 m(E-V)} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E t
$$

The neutrons are separated at point $B$ into two beams 1 and 2 , for which $\varphi_{B_{1}}=\varphi_{B_{2}}$.

The situations on lines $\mathrm{BC}$ and $\mathrm{DE}$ are same and so for the two neutron beams, $\Delta \varphi_{C B}=\Delta \varphi_{E D}$. On line $\mathrm{BD}$, we can set the gravitational potential $V=0, E=E_{0}$, and so

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \varphi_{D B} &=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{S} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} \cdot \frac{S}{v_{0}} \\
&=\frac{1}{\hbar}\left(\sqrt{2 m E_{0}} S-\frac{1}{2} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} S\right)=\frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

where $v_{0}$ is the neutron velocity $\frac{1}{m} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}$.

On line CE, the gravitational potential is

$$
V=m g h=m g \cdot \overline{B E} \sin \theta \sin \phi, \quad \text { with } \overline{B E}=2 S \cos \theta
$$

i.e.,

$$
V=m g S \sin 2 \theta \sin \phi
$$

and

$$
\begin{aligned}
\Delta \varphi_{E C} &=\frac{1}{\hbar} \int_{0}^{S} \sqrt{2 m\left(E_{0}-V\right)} d x-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} t \\
&=\frac{S}{\hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}} \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}-\frac{1}{\hbar} E_{0} \frac{S}{\sqrt{\frac{2\left(E_{0}-V\right)}{m}}} \\
&=S \frac{\sqrt{2 m E_{0}}}{2 \hbar}\left(2 \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}-\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}}\right) .
\end{aligned}
$$

Thus the phase difference of the two beams of neutrons at point $F$ is

$$
\begin{aligned}
\beta &=\Delta \varphi_{D B}-\Delta \varphi_{E C}=\frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}\left(1-2 \sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}+\frac{1}{\sqrt{1-\frac{V}{E_{0}}}}\right) \\
& \approx \frac{S}{2 \hbar} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}\left[1-2\left(1-\frac{V}{2 E_{0}}\right)+\left(1+\frac{V}{2 E_{0}}\right)\right] \\
&=\frac{3 V S}{4 \hbar E_{0}} \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}
\end{aligned}
$$

as $V \ll E_{0}$. Thus

$$
\beta=q \sin \phi,
$$

where

$$
\begin{aligned}
q & \approx \frac{3}{2} \frac{m^{2} g}{\hbar \sqrt{2 m E_{0}}} S^{2} \sin 2 \theta \\
&=K \lambda S^{2} \sin 2 \theta
\end{aligned}
$$

with

$$
\begin{aligned}
\lambda &=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{p}=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{\sqrt{2 m E_{0}}} \\
K &=\frac{3}{4} \frac{m^{2} g}{\pi \hbar^{2}}
\end{aligned}
$$The neutron has momentum

$$
p=\frac{h}{\lambda}=\frac{2 \pi \hbar}{\lambda}
$$

and hence kinetic energy

$$
\begin{aligned}
E_{k} &=\frac{p^{2}}{2 m}=\frac{2}{m c^{2}}\left(\frac{\pi \hbar c}{\lambda}\right)^{2} \\
&=\frac{2}{939 \times 10^{6}}\left(\frac{\pi \times 1.97 \times 10^{-5}}{1.45 \times 10^{-8}}\right)^{2} \\
&=0.039 \mathrm{eV}
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement:
A beam of electrons is scattered by a fixed scattering target as shown in the figure. The electrons are elastically scattered. Each electron has an energy $E=\frac{5}{3} m_{0} c^{2}$ and the beam has a flux of $Q$ electrons per second.

What is the velocity of the incident electrons?
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Units: $\mathrm{m/s}$. FLOAT. Units: $\mathrm{m/s}$. We let the velocity of light be $c = 3.0\times 10^8 \mathrm{m/s}$. Answer in the form $r\times 10^k$ where $r\in [0,10)$ and $k$ is an integer. Round $r$ to 1 decimal point.
Solution: As $E=m_{0} \gamma c^{2}=\frac{5}{3} m_{0} c^{2}, \gamma=\frac{5}{3}$ and $\frac{v}{c}=\sqrt{1-\frac{1}{\gamma^{2}}}=\frac{4}{5}$. Hence the electron velocity is $0.8 c$.

Problem Statement:
The energy levels of the four lowest states of an atom are

$$
\begin{aligned}
&E_{\mathrm{o}}=-14.0 \mathrm{eV} \\
&E_{1}=-9.0 \mathrm{eV} \\
&E_{2}=-7.0 \mathrm{eV} \\
&E_{3}=-5.5 \mathrm{eV}
\end{aligned}
$$

and the transition rates $A_{i j}$ (Einstein's $A$ coefficients) for the $i \rightarrow j$ transitions are

$$
\begin{aligned}
& A_{10}=3.0 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, \quad A_{20}=1.2 \times 10^{8} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, \quad A_{30}=4.5 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, \\
& A_{21}=8.0 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, \quad A_{31}=0, \quad A_{32}=1.0 \times 10^{7} \mathrm{~s}^{-1} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Imagine a vessel containing a substantial number of atoms in the level $E_{2}$

Calculate the radiative lifetime of the $E_{2}$ level.
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Units: $\mathrm{~s}$. Answer in the form $r\times 10^k$ where $r\in [0,10)$ and $k$ is an integer. $r$ should be rounded to 1 decimal point.
Solution:
The energy emitted per unit time is given by $\left(E_{i}-E_{j}\right) A_{i j}$, and so the ratio is

$$
\frac{E_{2}-E_{0}}{E_{2}-E_{1}} \cdot \frac{A_{20}}{A_{21}}=\frac{7}{2} \cdot \frac{12}{8}=5.25 .
$$An atom at level $E_{2}$ can transit to $E_{0}$ or $E_{1}$ through spontaneous transition. So the decrease in the number of such atoms in the time period $d t$ is 

$$
d N_{2}=-\left(A_{20}+A_{21}\right) N_{2} d t .
$$

i.e.,

$$
\frac{d N_{2}}{N_{2}}=-\left(A_{20}+A_{21}\right) d t
$$

or, by integration,

$$
N_{2}=N_{20} \exp \left[-\left(A_{20}+A_{21}\right) t\right],
$$

where $N_{20}$ is the number of atoms at energy level $E_{2}$ at time $t=0$. The mean lifetime is then

$$
\begin{aligned}
\tau &=\frac{1}{N_{20}} \int_{t=0}^{\infty} t\left(-d N_{2}\right)=\left(A_{20}+A_{21}\right) \int_{0}^{\infty} t \exp \left[-\left(A_{20}+A_{21}\right) t\right] d t \\
&=\frac{1}{A_{20}+A_{21}}=5.0 \times 10^{-9} \mathrm{~s} .
\end{aligned}
$$

Problem Statement: The current-voltage characteristic of the output terminals A, B (see the figure) is the same as that of a battery of emf $\varepsilon_{0}$ and internal resistance $r$. Find the short-circuit current provided by the battery.
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Units: $\mathrm{A}$. Round to 3 decimal points.
Solution:
According to Thévenin's theorem, the equivalent emf is the potential across $\mathrm{AB}$ when the output current is zero, i.e., the open-circuit voltage:

$$
\varepsilon_{0}=V_{\mathrm{AB}}=\frac{6}{24+6} \times 15=3 \mathrm{~V}
$$

The equivalent internal resistance is the resistance when the battery is shorted, i.e., the parallel combination of the resistances:

$$
r=\frac{6 \times 24}{6+24}=4.8 \Omega .
$$

Then the short-circuit current provided by the battery is

$$
I=\frac{\varepsilon_{0}}{r}=\frac{3 \mathrm{~V}}{4.8 \Omega}=0.625 \mathrm{~A}
$$

Problem Statement: An organ pipe of length $l$ open on both ends is used in a subsonic wind tunnel to measure the Mach number $v / c$ of air in the tunnel as shown in the figure. The pipe when fixed in the tunnel is observed to resonate with a fundamental period $t$. If $v / c=1 / 2$, calculate the ratio of periods $t / t_{0}$ where $t_{0}$ is the fundamental period of the pipe in still air.
Solution:
As the organ pipe is open at both ends, the fundamental wavelength of sound in resonance with it is given by $\lambda / 2=l$. The corresponding period is 

Fig. 1.221.

$$
t=\frac{\lambda}{v}=\frac{2 l}{v} \text {, }
$$

where $v$ is the velocity of sound relative to the pipe.

When the air in the pipe is still, $v$ is equal to the velocity of sound in still air, $c$, and the fundamental period is

$$
t_{0}=\frac{2 l}{c} .
$$

When the air in the pipe moves with velocity $c / 2$, the pipe can be considered to move with velocity $-c / 2$ in still air. Thus $v=c-(-c / 2)=$ $3 \mathrm{c} / 2$ and the period is

$$
t=\frac{2 l}{\frac{3 c}{2}}=\frac{4 l}{3 c} .
$$

Hence we have the ratio

$$
\frac{t}{t_{0}}=\frac{2}{3} .
$$

Problem Statement:
When displaced and released, the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ mass in the figure oscillates on the frictionless horizontal surface with period $\pi / 6$ seconds.

If a small mass is placed on the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ block and the coefficient of static friction between the small mass and the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ block is $0.1$, what is the maximum amplitude of oscillation before the small mass slips? (Assume the period is unaffected by adding the small mass.)
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Units: $\mathrm{~m}$. Answer in the form $r\times 10^k$ where $r\in [0,10)$ and $k$ is an integer. $r$ should be rounded to 1 decimal point.
Solution:
Let $k$ be the spring constant. The equation of the motion of the mass is

$$
2 \ddot{x}+k x=0,
$$

or

$$
\ddot{x}+\omega^{2} x=0,
$$

where $x$ is the displacement of the block from its equilibrium postition, and $\omega^{2}=\frac{k}{2}$. The general solution is

$$
x=A \cos (\omega t+\phi) .
$$

The period of oscillation is

$$
T=\frac{2 \pi}{\omega}=2 \pi \sqrt{\frac{2}{k}}=\frac{\pi}{6},
$$

giving $\omega=12 \mathrm{~s}^{-1}, k=288 \mathrm{Nm}^{-1}$. If $\dot{x}=x_{0}$ at $t=0$, then $\phi=0, A=x_{0}$ and the solution is $x=x_{0} \cos (12 t)$.

The force needed is

$$
f=k x=288 \times 2 \times 10^{-2}=5.76 \mathrm{~N} .
$$

If the small mass moves together with the $2 \mathrm{~kg}$ block, it has the same acceleration as the latter, i.e. $\ddot{x}=-144 x_{0} \cos (12 t)$. Let its mass be $m$. When it starts to slip, the maximum horizontal force on it just exceeds the static friction:

$$
0.1 \times m g=144 m x_{0},
$$

giving

$$
x_{0}=\frac{0.98}{144}=6.8 \times 10^{-3} \mathrm{~m} \text {. }
$$

If $x_{0}$ exceeds this value $m$ will slip. Hence it gives the maximum amplitude for no slipping.

Problem Statement:
Two flat plates, each $5 \mathrm{~cm}$ in diameter, one copper, one zinc (and both fitted with insulating handles), are placed in contact (see the figure) and then briskly separated.

Estimate the maximum charge one might expect to find on each plate after complete $(\gg 5 \mathrm{~cm})$ separation.
Output Format Instructions: FLOAT. Units: $\mathrm{~C}$. Answer in the form $r\times 10^k$ where $r\in [0,10)$ and $k$ is an integer. $r$ should be rounded to 1 decimal point.
Solution:
When the two plates are in contact, they can be taken as a parallelplate capacitor. Letting $\delta$ be their separation and $V$ be the potential difference, the magnitude of charge on each plate is

$$
Q=C V=\frac{\pi \varepsilon_{0}\left(\frac{d}{2}\right)^{2} V}{\delta} .
$$

As $d=0.05 \mathrm{~m}$, taking the contact potential as $V \sim 10^{-3} \mathrm{~V}$ and $\delta \sim 10^{-10} \mathrm{~m}$ we obtain

$$
Q \approx 1.7 \times 10^{-7} \mathrm{C} \text {. }
$$
